tweets.text: if you are putting out a paper draft, and you are having all the figures at the end of it just because it is more convenient for the journals to process it. I despise you. Do you not care about whether people would enjoy reading it? Do you even enjoy reading it yourself? Do you actually care about sharing your knowledge and experience? Or do you just care about getting it published? I hope I never have to work with you, I would never hire someone like you, and I would tell my friends coworkers random kids I met on the street dont be like you.

[Maia 200: The AI accelerator built for inference]( https://blogs.microsoft.com/blog/2026/01/26/maia-200-the-ai-accelerator-built-for-inference/) <III> agentic coding, competence cliffs, and the weird new shape of “trust” something clicked for me over the last couple months: i’m not “using an llm to code” anymore, i’m delegating. i still open the same repo and i still care about correctness, but the unit of work changed. i used to think in lines and functions. now i think in moves. “add a caching layer but don’t change behavior.” “write the slow correct version first, then optimize while keeping tests green.” “make the failure mode legible.” i feel mildly embarrassed admitting this, because it reads like i’m outsourcing craft. but the leverage is too real. and i don’t buy the vibe that this kills the ide. the ide is now the cockpit. the agent is the very talented intern with infinite stamina and a tendency to confidently misunderstand you if you let it. so my flow is: agent does the big chunk, ide is where i interrogate it like a lawyer. the failure modes are not the old ones. syntax errors are basically gone. instead you get: silent assumptions (“i assumed you meant postgres not sqlite”) conceptual near-misses (it’s 90% correct but the 10% is exactly the landmine) abstraction bloat (three layers of indirection for a two-line transformation) cleanup negligence (dead code and unused flags left like wrappers on the floor) and here’s the uncomfortable part: i’ve noticed my own atrophy. not at reading code—i can still spot weirdness—but at writing from scratch. generation and discrimination are different muscles. the agent is basically a backhoe: you still need to know what a good foundation looks like, but you’re not swinging the shovel all day. the price is you get less reps with the shovel. the second thing i didn’t anticipate: trust becomes the central bottleneck, not intelligence. the models are smart enough to produce plausible systems. they are not consistently honest about uncertainty. they don’t naturally say “i’m not sure, here are the tradeoffs, here’s what i’d verify.” you have to force that behavior with constraints: tests, invariants, explicit success criteria, “show me the assumptions you’re making,” etc. this connects to the personal-agent hype too. everyone wants the bot that lives on your machine, texts you first, runs while you sleep, plugs into email/calendar/messages. and yeah, the ergonomics are intoxicating. but the moment you wire an agent into your real life, opsec is now product design. you’re not “setting up a tool,” you’re defining an attack surface. permissions become existential. logging becomes evidence. “helpfulness” becomes indistinguishable from “capable of doing damage.” my current belief is boring but firm: if you give an agent access to anything consequential, you need a few non-negotiables: least privilege by default explicit approvals for sends/edits (not just reads) auditable logs you can independently verify clear boundaries on what it can do while you’re away a habit of skepticism even when it’s being charming and looping back to the “platonic representations” idea: if powerful learners converge on similar internal coordinates, that’s exciting. but it also means capability transfers fast. when the “shape” of solutions becomes shared, the main differentiator becomes governance: how systems are integrated, constrained, and monitored. tldr: i’m coding faster, building more, and having more fun—while getting more paranoid about correctness and trust. 2026 feels like the year we learn that “agentic” isn’t a feature. it’s a whole new failure domain.

sometimes I wish I could shrink these theory people and let them dig out their cavity design shovel by shovel. honestly I'd dig it too, only if we could shrink ourselves. this is pursuing smaller mode volume, which is about getting the resonant field of the mode to be as confined as possible, and then use it for sensing or coupling to an atom or emitter. But then you also have to put whatever stuff you want the cavity mode to couple to right at that spot..
look there is even a connecting rod, how considerate - Christiansen2024: [Orders-of-magnitude reduction in photonic mode volume by nano-sculpting]( https://arxiv.org/abs/2406.16461)

it's about how GaAs/AlGaAs crystalline coatings are better than dielectric coatings - Penn2019: [Mechanical ringdown studies of large-area substrate-transferred GaAs/AlGaAs crystalline coatings]( https://doi.org/10.1364/JOSAB.36.000C15)

people don't appreciate 1e-18 fractional accuracy enough. It took decades of development pushing many things to the extreme. For example, let's take a look at the optical cavity used for stabilizing the laser used for these atomic clocks. The most recent fight they had with the cavity is replacing the dielectric coating (sputtered SiO2/Ta2O5 or TiO2), which is amorphous, to stacks of crystalline GaAs/AlGaAs, because crystals have lower thermal mechanical noise than amorphous materials, and they got a cavity with 2.5e-17 stability with such quieter mirror coatings. [Lee2026] How good is 2.5e-17? When you are here, you are at the extreme opposite of "nothing ever happens". Everything is happening, and everything affects you. Temperature? It gives you at least two big headaches, (temperature fluctuation) * (thermal expansion), and thermal noise itself. So you optimize the cavity shape, you use single crystal for both the mirror spacer as well as the mirrors themselves so they are less lossy and thus less noisy, and you bond them together along the same crystal orientation as closely as possible. You also cooldown the cavity to reduce thermal noise, not only that, but you also operate at the CTE zero crossing point so temperature fluctuation matters less, thats why you see 124 K and 17 K for silicon cavities. Even with zero CTE, you still need few mK temperature control. Away from zero CTE, it may need to be stabilized to sub uK level. If you glance into cavities working at 4 K (i.e. small but not at zero CTE), you'll see crazy thermal damping systems to smooth out the temperature fluctuation of the 4 K cryostat (~20 mK), as well as find claims like "we now require only mK level control of the room temperature enclosure". [Zhang2017, Robinson2019] (they said "only" because some older cavities were at room T and controlled to sub mK [Ludlow2007], and they got tricks to reduce effects from room T.) (temperature gradient also gives you headache, which is why they choose silicon over glass, for its much higher thermal conductivity) Next is vibration/acceleration. Nothing is rigid, the cryostat vibrates, the earth rotates, and your cavity changes shape. Thats another motivation for silicon over glass, for its higher Young's modulus. So you make the cavity shape as symmetric as possible, and make the mounting fixture as symmetric as possible, and align them with the crystal axis because silicon's Youngs modulus not isotropic . Thus you also choose the optical axis to be the crystal axis with the highest Young's modulus. [Kessler2012] You also gotta align the mechanical axis with the optical axis and with the crystal axis, otherwise longitudinal acceleration would tilt the mirrors and change cavity length. The spacer shape is also a double cone so that it sags less and bends less under transverse acceleration. [Millo2009] Any mechanical resonance would be bad, so you also gotta use PEEK instead of PTFE for supporting the mounting ring, and push the lowest mechanical resonance to be as high freq as possible. Remember silicon's crystal structure? Remember its 3-fold rotational symmetry? That's why your support structure also has the same 3-fold symmetry. [Matei2016] If you have done all these properly, congratulations, now you might be ready to start fighting thermal noise in the dielectric mirror coatings. Harry2002: [Thermal noise in interferometric gravitational wave detectors due to dielectric optical coatings]( http://doi.org/10.1088/0264-9381/19/5/305) Numata2004: [Thermal-Noise Limit in the Frequency Stabilization of Lasers with Rigid Cavities]( https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.93.250602) Ludlow2007: [Compact, thermal-noise-limited optical cavity for diode laser stabilization at 1e-15]( https://doi.org/10.1364/OL.32.000641) Millo2009: [Ultrastable lasers based on vibration insensitive cavities]( https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.93.250602) Hopcroft2010: [What is the Young's Modulus of Silicon?]( https://doi.org/10.1109/JMEMS.2009.2039697) Kessler2012: [A sub-40-mHz-linewidth laser based on a silicon single-crystal optical cavity]( https://doi.org/10.1038/nphoton.2012.217) Matei2016: [A second generation of low thermal noise cryogenic silicon resonators]( https://doi.org/10.1088/1742-6596/723/1/012031) Zhang2017: [Ultrastable Silicon Cavity in a Continuously Operating Closed-Cycle Cryostat at 4 K]( https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.93.250602) Robinson2019: [Crystalline optical cavity at 4 K with thermal-noise-limited instability and ultralow drift]( https://doi.org/10.1364/OPTICA.6.000240) Lee2026: [Frequency Stability of 2.5×10^−17 from a Si Cavity with AlGaAs Crystalline Mirrors]( https://doi.org/10.1103/zgrm-cjbb)
